bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, April 28, 1900

div1.p: Lazear writes about his living arrangements and his laboratory. He discusses the political situation in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, April 28, 1900
div1.opener:
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
Columbia Barracks
Havana Cuba
BALTIMORE Apr. 28. 1900
My dear Mother,
div1.p:
Thank you very much for
the birthday present. I wish I could
have a talk with you. Mabel
writes how nice you have been to
them. I am very comfortably fixed.

I have a nice little house all to
myself, and a laboratory in which
no one interferes and a soldier
to do the cleaning and anything I
tell him to do. There is hardly anyone
here who is so well fixed as
to quarters. All except General Baldwin
the commander of the post and Colonel
Ellis of the Infantry are in long
building with frame partitions through
which all noises are plainly heard.
My isolation is really a great luxury.
It does not seem too lonesome either
because a sentry guards us all night
long. Being in the country is a great
pleasure. It is always cooler here than
in Havana. I have not been in town
since Mabel left, but I may have
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
BALTIMORE.
to go in frequently later. I must
make the most of my stay here for
no one knows how soon the American
occupation may end. It all depends
on the game of politics.
Give my love to Aunt Kate.
